update.description:
**Update \(July 23, 2018\): **`RosFlashLightPlugin` was replaced with `RosLedPlugin`, which can control both light and visual objects. ***This PR depends on FlashLightPlugin/LedPlugin in Gazebo, which will be in the next release. It should be reviewed after then.***

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2763757140-Peek%202018-07-23%2010-29.gif)
‌

`RosLedPlugin` to handle <light> and <visual> objects attached on <link> elements** **through ROS service. The service name can be specified by a plugin parameter. If it is given without `/`, the scoped name of the model will be attached as a prefix. In the example, the model name is `light_model`, so lights are toggled by `rosservice call /light_model/light_switch true` and `rosservice call /light_model/light_switch false`.
update.title: Flashlight/LED ROS service plugin

update.description:
**Note: *This PR depends on FlashLightPlugin/LedPlugin in Gazebo, which will be in the next release. It should be reviewed after then.***

‌

**Update:** Changed the communication from transport to ROS service. The updated parts are highlighted.

Flashlight control plugin to handle flashlights attached on link elements** through ROS service**. **After starting the launch file \(flash\_light\_example.launch\), the flashlights can be toggled by running the command “rosservice call /light\_switch true” and “rosservice call /light\_switch false”.**

As the plugin \(LightControlPlugin\) **receives a call from a ROS service client**, and it turns on/off the flashlights, by calling the functions of its parent class \(FlashLightPlugin\), which is responsible for actual flashing control.

The parent class may be generic. I created a pull request for this class as a plugin to gazebo9. If it is accepted as a part of gazebo, this parent class may be replaced.

Testing code measures actual duration and interval time of the flashlights by listening to the topic “~/light/modify”. The test passes if the errors are equal to or less than 0.01 sec.**  
 ~~The testing code is not complete. It is to call a ROS service but it apparently hangs up when it calls it. Since the launch file works, this testing code may not correctly start ROS. I would appreciate any advice!~~  
 Now the testing code seems to work. \(roscore must run before the code runs\) My code did not spin for ROS callbacks. It has AsyncSpinner in it. I would appreciate any comments if I am not using it in a right way.**
update.title: Flashlight control plugin

The parent class may be generic. I created a pull request for this class as a plugin to gazebo9. If it is accepted as a part of gazebo, this parent class may be replaced.

Testing code measures actual duration and interval time of the flashlights by listening to the topic “~/light/modify”. The test passes if the errors are equal to or less than 0.01 sec.**

update.description:
**Update:** Changed the communication from transport to ROS service. The updated parts are highlighted.

Flashlight control plugin to handle flashlights attached on link elements** through ROS service**. **After starting the launch file \(flash\_light\_example.launch\), the flashlights can be toggled by running the command “rosservice call /light\_switch true” and “rosservice call /light\_switch false”.**

As the plugin \(LightControlPlugin\) **receives a call from a ROS service client**, and it turns on/off the flashlights, by calling the functions of its parent class \(FlashLightPlugin\), which is responsible for actual flashing control.

The parent class may be generic. I created a pull request for this class as a plugin to gazebo9. If it is accepted as a part of gazebo, this parent class may be replaced.

Testing code measures actual duration and interval time of the flashlights by listening to the topic “~/light/modify”. The test passes if the errors are equal to or less than 0.01 sec.**  
 ~~The testing code is not complete. It is to call a ROS service but it apparently hangs up when it calls it. Since the launch file works, this testing code may not correctly start ROS. I would appreciate any advice!~~  
 Now the testing code seems to work. \(roscore must run before the code runs\) My code did not spin for ROS callbacks. It has AsyncSpinner in it. I would appreciate any comments if I am not using it in a right way.**

‌
update.title: Flashlight control plugin

content.html: Nit: extra line.

content.html: Nit: We usually use < for external code (Gazebo and ROS are external dependencies here). See other includes too.

content.html: How about initialize it to "light_control" here and you can remove the next else block?

content.html: Maybe <service_name> is a simple name?

update.description:
**Update:** Changed the communication from transport to ROS service. The updated parts are highlighted.

Flashlight control plugin to handle flashlights attached on link elements** through ROS service**. **After starting the launch file \(flash\_light\_example.launch\), the flashlights can be toggled by running the command “rosservice call /light\_switch true” and “rosservice call /light\_switch false”.**

As the plugin \(LightControlPlugin\) **receives a call from a ROS service client**, and it turns on/off the flashlights, by calling the functions of its parent class \(FlashLightPlugin\), which is responsible for actual flashing control.

The parent class may be generic. I created a pull request for this class as a plugin to gazebo9. If it is accepted as a part of gazebo, this parent class may be replaced.

Testing code measures actual duration and interval time of the flashlights by listening to the topic “~/light/modify”. The test passes if the errors are equal to or less than 0.01 sec.**  
 ~~The testing code is not complete. It is to call a ROS service but it apparently hangs up when it calls it. Since the launch file works, this testing code may not correctly start ROS. I would appreciate any advice!~~  
 Now the testing code seems to work. \(roscore must run before the code runs\) My code did not spin for ROS callbacks. It has AsyncSpinner in it. I would appreciate any comments if I am not using it in a right way.**

‌
update.title: Flashlight control plugin

content.raw:
Yeah, I will document it. The name of the service is “light\_control” in default but it can also be overridden by a plugin parameter <main\_switch\_srvs> so each model has its own service name to turn on/off its lights attached on it. For example, a robot has two flashlights and a user can do like “rosservice call /flashlight1 true” and “rosservice call /flashlight2 false”  
Would it be a good idea if I define this default service name in CommonTypes.hh?
content.html:
Yeah, I will document it. The name of the service is “light_control” in default but it can also be overridden by a plugin parameter <main_switch_srvs> so each model has its own service name to turn on/off its lights attached on it. For example, a robot has two flashlights and a user can do like “rosservice call /flashlight1 true” and “rosservice call /flashlight2 false”
Would it be a good idea if I define this default service name in CommonTypes.hh?

content.raw: OK, I will.
content.html: OK, I will.

content.raw: Sorry… I will correct it.
content.html: Sorry… I will correct it.

content.raw: That’ll make more sense. Yes, I will rename it.
content.html: That’ll make more sense. Yes, I will rename it.

content.raw: Should the name of the service used to control the lights exposed as a parameter and documented here?
content.html: Should the name of the service used to control the lights exposed as a parameter and documented here?

content.raw: You can leave it for testing your PR if that was the original intent but we should remove it before merge it.
content.html: You can leave it for testing your PR if that was the original intent but we should remove it before merge it.

content.raw: **A** plugin…
content.html: A plugin…

content.raw: Could you rename this file to \`ROSFlashlightPlugin\`? Just use the same name as the Gazebo plugin with the `ROS` prefix if it’s just a ROS wrapper.
content.html: Could you rename this file to `ROSFlashlightPlugin`? Just use the same name as the Gazebo plugin with the ROS prefix if it’s just a ROS wrapper.

content.raw: Oh wait, this is the original Gazebo plugin. I don’t think we need it, it should be part of Gazebo9.
content.html: Oh wait, this is the original Gazebo plugin. I don’t think we need it, it should be part of Gazebo9.

content.raw: Could you rename the plugin files to ROSFlashLightPlugin? Remember to update the header guards.
content.html: Could you rename the plugin files to ROSFlashLightPlugin? Remember to update the header guards.
